main_definition: Threshold is the point at which a particular event or change occurs, often used to refer to the level of stimulus necessary to provoke an action or response.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A level-setting criterion that determines when something happens or changes
meanings_and_examples.example: The income threshold for qualifying for government assistance programs varies depending on family size.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A door sill or bottom strip of a gate, doorway, etc., which one has to step over to enter a room or building
meanings_and_examples.example: As I approached the threshold of my childhood home, memories flooded back with each creaking floorboard.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A standard used for comparison in an effort to measure up to it
meanings_and_examples.example: The new employee felt as though he was at a performance threshold compared to his colleagues who had more experience.

meanings_and_examples.definition: The minimum level of intensity or frequency required to produce a particular result
meanings_and_examples.example: Noise-canceling headphones must block out sounds below the decibel threshold that humans can hear.

meanings_and_examples.definition: A point of transition between two different states, conditions, or environments
meanings_and_examples.example: The coral snake's venom becomes active at its physiological threshold temperature and is no longer inert below this level.
